titleStmt.title: Internal Manipulation of Perceptual Representations in Human Flexible Cognition: A Computational Model

affiliation.orgName: Institute of Cognitive Sciences and Technologies
Institute of Cognitive Sciences and Technologies

analytic.title: Internal Manipulation of Perceptual Representations in Human Flexible Cognition: A Computational Model

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

abstract.p: Executive functions represent a wide set of goal-directed cognitive processes that rely on integrated cortical-basal ganglia brain systems and are at the basis of human flexible behaviour. Several computational models have been proposed to study cognitive flexibility and the Wisconsin Card Sorting Test (WCST), an important neuropsychological test used for measuring such function. These models clarify important aspects of cognitive flexibility, in particular the processes concerning decision making, motor response, and feedback-dependent learning. However, several studies suggest that categorisation processes, as those involved in the solution of the WCST, also involve a fundamental category representation stage supporting the other processes. Surprisingly, all models of the WCST ignore such fundamental stage and propose that decision making directly triggers actions. Here we propose a novel hypothesis for which the key element of cognitive flexibility resides on the acquisition of suitable representations of percepts, and their top-down internal manipulation, to prepare effective actions. We also propose a neuro-inspired computational model to operationalise the hypothesis. The model is validated by systematically reproducing and interpreting the behaviour of healthy young and old adults, and of frontal and Parkinson pathological patients. The hypothesis and model also allow the proposal of a new version of the WCST that might be used to further investigate the important role of the internal manipulation of representations here proposed to be at the core of flexible goal-directed behaviour.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Executive functions are a set of high-order processes that allow the expression of flexible behaviour. describes executive functions as "a family of top-down mental processes needed when you have to concentrate and pay attention, when going on automatic or relying on instinct or intuition would be ill-advised, insufficient, or impossible". This definition partially overlaps with the concept of goal-directed behaviour (GDB; , referring to processes and mechanisms able to flexibly generate effective associations between perceptions and actions on the basis of goals. These contrast the processes underlying habitual behaviour based on more direct and automatic associations between stimuli and responses.

Here we focus on goal-directed processes that support cognitive flexibility, an executive function that allows the switching between different behavioural strategies depending on external and internal conditions. This executive function is commonly measured through the Wisconsin Cards Sorting Test (WCST), a neuropsychological test that exists in many forms for humans and other species .

Several computational models, analysed in detail in Section 4, have been proposed to study cognitive flexibility and the WCST. These models focus on relevant issues concerning the WCST, such as its theoretical analysis , its solution by psychiatric patients , the variety of deficits it reveals , the neural working-memory dynamics involved in its solution , and the sequential learning processes it requires . Other models focus on the brain mechanisms underlying the solution of the test, such as the selection processes relying on basal ganglia or the working memory processes relying on dopamine signals .

These models contribute to clarify relevant aspects of the goal-directed processes supporting the cognitive flexibility needed to solve the WCST, in particular they focus on the processes of decision-making, response selection, and feedback-dependent learning underlying the task solution. However, an extensive experimental and theoretical literature (e.g., suggests that categorisation tasks, of which the WCST is an instance, rely on multiple stages involving category representation, decision making, motor response, and feedback-dependent learning. Surprisingly, none of the current models of the WCST studies the early processes of learning and manipulation of categories notwithstanding the core aspect of the test requires the participants to flexibly switch the categories through which they process and react to the test stimuli.

In this work we face this problem by proposing three novel contributions that offer a new perspective on the processes supporting flexible cognition. The first contribution is the proposal of the hypothesis for which the processes of top-down internal manipulation of representations, and their guidance of goaldirected embodied interactions with the environment, play a key role in flexible cognition. This hypothesis builds on previous proposals on goal-directed selective attention processes , claiming that goals drive the top-down selection of relevant parts of sensory input patterns, and on studies related to covert attention and imagination , claiming that the top-down activation of visual cortices can also support visual working memory and imagination processes in the absence of external stimuli. The hypothesis also linked to theories of embodied cognition that see cognitive processes and internal representations as strongly grounded on the interactions of the agents with the environment Barsalou, 2008;. Finally, the hypothesis is also driven by the recent progresses in machine learning that propose a parallelism between the internal functioning of generative neural networks, capable of producing 'plausible' images through internal processes , and the interaction between frontal cortices and visual cortices in the brain considered above. Overall the hypothesis, described in detail in Section 2.2, attributes a fundamental role to the brain capacity of selecting categories and use them to internally re-code perceptual stimuli that then trigger the execution of suitable actions accomplishing the desired goals, for example to solve the WCST.

The second contribution is the proposal of a new computational model that operationalises the proposed hypothesis. The model includes some processes that are conceptually analogous to those used in previous models, in particular a mechanism for selecting the behavioural rule to follow and an error processing mechanism to correct such selection. However, the model also presents a fundamental novelty deriving from our hypothesis, namely a system that can manipulate internal representations for solving tasks such as the WCST. This system relies on three key components: (a) an executive working memory storing possible categorisation rules that are used to deferentially interpret perceptual stimuli; (b) a visual working memory representing perceptual stimuli at different levels of abstraction; (c) an internal manipulator that selects the contents of the visual working memory on the basis of the categorisation rules stored in the executive working memory. The synergistic interaction between these components and sensorimotor processes allows the embodied model to interact with the environment and express flexible behaviour. This can lead to the solution of the WCST based on the active switching of internal embodied representations of stimuli rather than of actions, as done by all previous models of the WCST. We validated the model proposed here by reproducing the data of different human groups who solved the WCST (early adults, old adults, frontal patients, and Parkinson's patients). Moreover, we performed various 'lesions' of the model (based on the manipulation of key model parameters), reproducing specific alterations in the brain, to show the contribution of the different processes of the model to the production of different types of errors exhibited by humans performing the WCST.

The third contribution is a deeper study of the model core system performing the manipulation of the internal representations. In particular, we investigated how the visual working memory, biased by the executive working memory, might manage to maintain an internal representation of relevant object features during stimulus-response time delays during which the system perceives distracting stimuli. This allows the study of how the top-down bias on lower-level representations can counteract the disturbing effect of the distractors. Based on this letter study, we finally propose a new version of the WCST aimed to more directly test our hypothesis on the pivotal role played by the internal manipulation of representations for flexible goal-directed behaviour.

div.head: Methods
div.p: In this section we first illustrate the version of the WCST used here to test the model, then we present the architecture and functioning of the model, and finally we consider the techniques used to analyse the model.

div.head: The Wisconsin Card Sorting Test (WCST) and the brain processes involved in its solution
div.p: Materials and procedure. In the WCST (Figure 1, on top) the participants have to match a card drawn from a deck (called 'response-card' or 'deck-card') to one of four sample cards (called 'stimulus-cards' or 'target-cards'). Each card contains coloured items having a unique combination of features. These features are differentiated in three categories, each involving four attributes: (1) colour: red, green, blue, or yellow; (2) form: stars, triangles, circles, or crosses; (3) number: one, two, three, or four elements. The participant is requested to bring the deck card close to one of the target cards by trying to match them in terms of either the colour, form, or number. A first key element of the test is that the correct rule for matching the cards is not told to the participant: after each action, an operator furnishes a 'correct' or 'incorrect' feedback based on the current matching rule and on this basis the participant has to infer the correct rule. A second key challenge of the test, probing in particular cognitive flexibility, is that the correct matching rule changes after a certain number of uninterrupted correct actions, so the participant has to search and switch to the new rule based on the sole information from the feedback. To pass the test the participant has to complete a certain number of uninterrupted card sequences each involving a different rule.

There are many versions of the WCST differing in the test procedure or the performance score. We used the Heatons' version of the test having these specific features: (a) participants can use up to two decks of 64 cards; (b) completing a category set requires ten correct matches in sequence; (c) after completion of a category set the sorting rule changes without the participant being told; (d) to pass the test the participant has to complete a series involving six different correct matching rules: colour, form, number, colour, form, number; (e) if the participant uses both decks without completing the series of categories, the test is considered 'failed'.

The WCST is similar to another test, the match-to-sample task, used to probe working memory (e.g., . The classic match-to-sample task requires to remember a cue on the basis of which the participant has to select, after a short time delay, one of two items where only one of the two is equal or related to the cue. Also the WCST puts a strong demand on working memory but in addition it also requires to actively manipulate its contents, in particular the information related to the possible correct matching rule to use next.

The WCST also involves many processes shared with classical categorisation tasks, in which a participant has to classify an input respect a specific rule (e.g., . Differently from categorisation tasks, in the WCST the categorisation rule dynamically changes based on both the participant's actions and a prefixed order, and this requires a higher cognitive load.

Scoring and types of errors. For the test scoring we followed the official documentation of the test , in particular we used five principal indices giving a full profile of the participants' performance (see the documentation for a thorough explanation of the indices):
• Completed Categories (CC): this index, ranging in (0, 6), indicates the number of successfully completed categories; the index scores the global performance.
• Total Errors (TE): total incorrect responses, including both PE and NPE (see below); this index scores the level of global deficit.
• Perseverative Errors (PE): cards sorted with the same incorrect rule after a negative feedback error; the index indicates a perseverative behaviour.
• Non Perseverative Errors (NPE): errors not included in PE; these errors occur in different situations and they could suggest an attentional failure or an incorrect inferential reasoning.
• Failure to Maintain Set (FMS): whatever errors occurring after five consecutive correct matches.

Neural correlates of the behaviour exhibited during the WCST solution. The model we present here is biologically inspired in that it reproduces some important functions and mechanisms commonly ascribed to relevant brain systems. This section briefly mentions the literature we considered to design the model. Notice that for its scope, focused on the system-level operationalisation of the internal representation manipulation hypothesis, the model reproduces the relevant functions and lesions of the brain areas discussed here mostly at a functional level, in particular without reproducing the specific features of the underlying anatomy and physiology of the brain. The literature proposes various partially-overlapping interpretations on the neural correlates of the behaviour exhibited by WCST participants. Figure 2 represents both a schematic brain overview of highly activated areas during the WCST, and lesions sites related to specific errors occurring during the test. To build the diagram, we analysed the works reported in the meta-review of , focusing in particular on data having a spatial resolution at the level of specific cortical areas for the activations and the indication of the specific sites of the lesions (Table S1 in Supplementary Materials illustrates the specific lesions considered and the literature supporting them).

Figure 2: Left: The brain areas that are highly active during the WCST performance. The colour and size of circles indicates the number of papers we considered that found a specific activation site (small/green: < 3; large/orange ≥ 3). Right: Sites of lesions that cause specific errors during the WCST. The colour intensity of the bolt arrows suggests the specificity of lesions (transparent: distributed lesions; dark: focused lesions). For both graphs, see Table S1 in Supplementary Materials for the literature supporting this overview.

This analysis indicates that the brain areas that are highly involved in the WCST performance are the fronto-parietal cortices, supporting goal-directed perception and attention , sub-cortical structures (in particular basal ganglia), supporting the processing of reward , frontal structures such as the orbital cortex and the ventro-medial prefrontal cortex, supporting emotional processing, and the anterior cingulate cortex, supporting error detection . Several studies (e.g., indicate that these frontal, parietal and sub-cortical systems form an integrated network of systems underpinning cognitive flexibility and other executive cognitive functions. Figure 2 also summarises the relation between errors occurring during the WCST performance and different lesion sites. In this respect, coherently with the functional interpretation of the active areas seen in healthy participants and discussed above, the neuropsychological literature highlights: (a) a correlation between perseverative errors and both sub-cortical and medial cortex impaired sites; (b) a correlation between most types of errors and superior frontal lesion sites. In particular, PE are considered an indicator of flexibility impairment related to the incapacity to change a behavioural rule that has been successful up to a certain time (e.g., . Alongside these classical interpretations focused on PE, some studies articulate the meaning of the NPE and FMS errors. Among these, suggests that NPE are related to attentional or reasoning failures, while link them to attention and working memory dysfunctions. focus on FMS errors suggesting that they reflect distractibility rather than a cognitive flexibility deficit.

div.head: A three-component hypothesis on the flexible manipulation of internal representations
div.p: In this section we propose a theoretical hypothesis of the brain internal manipulation of perceptual representations underlying the solution of the WCST. The top-down modulation of the activation of internal representations is a brain mechanism based on the application of an activation bias to information flows exchanged by cortex . Many studies (e.g., suggest that this mechanism supports the extraction of external input features, the top-down biased selection of relevant information (selective attention), the internal persistent maintenance of information in the absence of external input (imagination) for example related to goals and anticipated action outcomes. We propose that all these processes rely on the interplay of three fundamental systems (Figure 3; cf. : (a) a system storing goals and behavioural rules; (b) a system extracting and storing perceptual representations; (c) a system manipulating perceptual representations on the basis of goals and behavioural rules. We now consider the interplay of these three systems, operationalised in the computational model, and for concreteness we exemplify how they might work while performing the WCST. The colour gradient (red to blue) indicates a gradual change of computational functions from those encoding goals and behavioural rules (red; fronto-striatal areas) to those encoding percepts (blue; dorso-caudal areas).

The more abstract amodal executive working memory , relying on fronto-striatal networks, selects and stores, on the basis of motivational drives, the overall goal to pursue (e.g., obtaining a positive feedback in the WCST) and the possible sub-goals to accomplish it (e.g., the behavioural rules linked to the card features to match). Such high-level goals and sub-goals are encoded as perceptual representations resulting from the abstraction processes of perceptual cortical hierarchies.

The fronto-parietal cortical system, based on perceptual attentional processes supported by basal-ganglia selection mechanisms , furnishes a top-down bias to the lower-level competition processes taking place within sensory cortices. This bias is driven by the behavioural rules stored in the executive working memory and is led by them to support the selection of alternative contents within the perceptual cortical system (e.g., the colour rather than the shape of the elements in the card).

The perceptual cortical system transmits sensory information to the higher-level cognitive systems. This perceptual system , excited by the top-down biases, also implements a perceptual working memory storing input selected features. In particular, the top-down bias leads the system to encode in a stronger way perceptual representations that are relevant to accomplish the pursued goal (e.g., specific features of cards based on different possible card sorting rules). Figure 4 highlights how the three systems encompassed by the hypothesis interplay to support the processes underlying the solution of the WCST. In particular, it shows how the sub-goals (behavioural rules linked to specific categories) stored in executive working memory fuel a selection process that leads to choosing specific contents of the perceptual working memory. Under this bias, the perceptual working memory generates a representation of the deck card suitable to compare it with a target card with respect to the chosen category, and thus to guide downstream motor processes. Our hypothesis and model agree with empirical evidence on the brain macro architecture showing how prefrontal cortex is strongly connected with parietal cortex as much as, or even more, than with motor areas; the parietal cortex in turn exerts a strong control on motor areas . Functionally, the parietal cortex plays a key role in controlling action on the basis of the representation of the features of objects, such as their position and size, relevant to interact with them : these representations are thus said to encode affordances ; an action affordance can be intended as an agent's activated internal representation of the preconditions necessary for the successful accomplishment of the action, . Our proposal contrasts the hypothesis, summarised in Figure 4, that emerges from previous models of the WCST. According to these models, the high-level selection of the category rule directly biases the selection of the motor responses rather than the lower-level perceptual representations.

div.head: Overview of the functioning of the model components and their biological underpinnings
div.p: This section illustrates the architecture of the model, in particular the functioning of its components, the information flow between them, and their biological underpinnings. The model architecture operationalises the three-fold hypothesis related to the manipulation of perceptual representations illustrated in the previous section, and also encompasses auxiliary components needed to have an agent able to interact with the environment and form realistic representations of the cards. The model architecture and components are summarised in Figure 5 and are now explained in detail. Visual sensor. This component corresponds to the eye retina. The sensor is actuated and so that it can focus on one card at a time (see below). The sensor returns a visual image of the cards: the sensor is large enough so that a focused card wholly falls within its scope.

Perceptual component. This component is a layered neural network performing a bottom-up processing of the visual images analogously to what happens in the human perceptual system involving striate and extra-striate visual cortices. The component reflects the hierarchical nature of these cortices involving many levels of information processing, from the low-level retinotopic visual processing of features in striate cortex (V1), to the processing of higher-level image proprieties (shape, colour, etc.) in extra-striate cortices (V2 to V5) and different areas of infero-temporal and parietal cortex . The component also implements a perceptual working-memory, storing the features extracted from perceptual stimuli, that in the brain is supported by modal sensory cortices .

Reward/motivation component. This component processes the input to compute the system's internal reward signals and gives a motivational bias to the working memory processes. In brain, these processes rely on ventral basal ganglia , the ventro-medial PFC, and the ventral ACC .

Executive working-memory. This component reproduces the functions of executive/abstract working memory, in particular it stores the possible sub-goals corresponding to the possible card matching rules. Executive working memory is supported by brain systems such as the dorsal-lateral portions of PFC that can store information on goals and behavioural strategies through recurrent circuits , and can select them based on lateral inhibition mechanisms . As in brain working memory , the model working memory component implements these key processes (cf. : (a) the active maintenance of sub-goals in the absence of the perception of the corresponding stimuli; (b) the release (forgetting) of such information when it is no more relevant.

Perceptual manipulator. This component supports two processes. The first process involves the decision of the behavioural rules depending on the activation of the executive working-memory. This process mimics the role of the dorsal ACC in affective decision making . The second process involves the performance of the actual top-down manipulation of the perceptual contents of the perceptual system. The manipulation is based on a disinhibition mechanism that reproduces a main feature of the functioning of basal ganglia . This mechanism inhibits all internal representations activated by the bottom-up sensory information with the exception of the one that corresponds to the card matching rule to follow. In this way, only the colour or form or size features are used to compare the deck and target cards. The manipulator also employs a local selection process to enhance the activation of specific features seen in the stimuli and in agreement with the top-down bias (e.g., to select 'red' if the chosen behavioural rule is 'colour'). This process mimics the top-down modulation of the high-level cortices exerted on the lower sensory cortices via the fronto-parietal cortical system .

Visual comparator. This component compares the deck card and the foveated target card and returns their level of similarity ('visual matching'). This component is inspired by findings related to same/not-same tasks that have been shown to rely on the interplay between occipital/temporal cortices and dlPFC.

Motor components. A first motor component moves the visual sensor to scan the different target cards to search the one that matches the deck card based on the selected matching rule. This last mechanism guides the gaze in a top-down manner based on the visual comparator output: when there is not a visual match, this mechanism triggers a saccade that shifts the fovea to the following target card; when a match is found, the mechanism stops the gaze on the current target card and releases the arm action. When this happens, a second motor component controls a simulated manipulator that moves the deck card close to the selected target card as requested by the WCST. Note that here it is assumed that these attentional scanning and object-moving behaviours are acquired before the solution of the WCST and triggered by the top-down processes.

Bottom-up perceptual processes and top-down attentional processes. The model implements bottom-up and top-down information flows respectively corresponding to perception and attention processes . Perception involves the bottom-up transmission and progressive abstraction of visual information from the retina to higher cortical levels. Attention and imagination involve a top-down information flow through which brain frontal areas can activate or bias peripheral perceptual areas so that they tend to have a stronger activation in correspondence to relevant external stimuli (attention; or even to activate in the absence of them (imagination; ). In the model, the selection of a specific matching rule within the working memory, and the consequent dishinibition of a certain attribute representation, starts a top-down activation flow that leads to generate images, at the lower levels of the perceptual component, that correspond to the selected attribute. The model uses this processes to 'filter' the input images of the deck card and of the target card under focus in order to compare them with respect to the current matching rule (i.e., either colour, shape, or size).

A relevant feature of the model is that it compares the deck and target cards at the low perceptual level. This comparison could have been performed on the basis of the high-level representations of cards, for example at the last layer of the perceptual component. As discussed in Section2.2, the comparison taking place at the low-level mimics the brain functioning. Moreover, it might also have these computational advantages: (a) the possibility of exploiting the detailed information coming from the sensors, suitably selected by the top-down processes, to carry out operations that depend on it (e.g., operations that depend on the detailed shape of objects; ; (b) the possibility of using high-level abstract representations to generate lower-level detailed representations through information gathered 'along the way' from the intermediate representation levels; this more detailed information can then be useful to support processes needing it, for example fine-level comparisons .

Interaction loops. The functioning of the model involves three interaction loops with the environment (Figure 5) and these lead the model to perceive visual stimuli (images) having a substantial level of realism. A first 'attentional loop' involves the motion of the visual sensor, the processing of the image by the perceptual component, and the visual comparison of the deck card with the focused target card. A second 'object-displacement loop' involves the motor system displacing the objects and affecting the following visual perception. The third 'feedback-manipulation loop', the more complex and indirect of the three loops, processes the feedback to produce reward, uses it to update the relevance of the matching rule stored in the executive working-memory, and then selects a category representation. On this basis, the loop exerts a top-down bias on the operation of the other two loops.

These loops, involving circular interactions between the system components and the environment, give the model some elements of embodiment in that its actions affect its sensory input and internal representations, and this aspects enter the solutions found for solving the task . Although representing a simplified form of embodiment, the loops capture the essence of the sensorimotor interactions involved in the solution of the WCST and are sufficient for the study of the top-down perceptual manipulation mechanism proposed here. At the same time, these elements are relevant to study the links between embodiment and flexible cognition, for example the model stops scanning of the target cards when it finds one that matches the deck card according to the selected behaviour rule: this triggers the action and the consequent feedback retroacting on the behaviour of the model.

div.head: Computational details of the model
div.p: This section explains the key computational features of the model, summarised in Figure 6. Further details and equations on the model functioning and learning are presented in the Supplementary Materials. The code of the model will be made available online in GitHub for public download in case of publication.

Algorithm 1 overviews the information flowing between the model components, the computations they perform, and the interactions of the model with the environment. The algorithm involves a first cycle (line Algorithm 1 Model: Information flows, computations, and interaction loops with the environment.
div.formula: 1: for deckCard ∈ {1, 2, ..., 64} do 2: (deckCardImage, deckCardPosition) ← VisionComponentScan(deckCard) 3: attributePreactivation ← DBNForwardSpreading(deckCardImage) 4: category ← SoftMax(workingMemory) 5: attribute ← DisinhibitionOfCategoryAttributes(attributePreactivation, category) 6: reconstructedDeckCard ← DBNGeneration(attribute) 7: match ← F alse 8:
div.p: for targetCard ∈ {1, 2, 3, 4} AND match = F alse do 9:
attribute ← DihinibitionOfCategoryAttributes(attributePreactivation, category)
div.formula: reconstructedTargCard ← DBNGeneration(attribute) 13: match ← VisualComparision(reconstructedTargCard, reconstructedDeckCard) 14: MotorComponentMoveDeckCard(targetCardPosition,deckCardPosition) 15: feedback ← GetFeedback() 16:
div.p: UpdateWorking(feedback) 1) corresponding to the cards drawn from the deck. The system visually scans the drawn deck card (line 2) and then processes its features corresponding to the currently selected matching rule, stored in the working memory, and memorises them for later use (lines 3-6; a non-neural memory is used to this purpose). A second nested cycle allows the model to visually scan the target cards in sequence (line 8): for each target card the model reconstructs its features corresponding to the currently selected matching rule (lines 9-12) and then compares them with those of the deck card stored in memory (line 13). When a target card matches the deck card, the model stops scanning the target cards, moves the former below the last scanned target card (line 14), and collects the corresponding feedback (line 15). Lastly, the model uses the feedback to update the working memory (lines 16).

Environment. The agent acts in a simulated environment formed by a squared space of 100 × 100 pixels. The environment contains 'objects' that the model can visually explore and move in space (see Figure 6). Objects are here cards representing polygons each characterised by a unique combination of three visual properties, each having one of four possible attributes: colour (red, green, blue, yellow), form (square, circle, triangle, bar), size (large, medium-large, medium-small, small). This set of attributes generates 4 3 = 64 combinations (cards). With respect to the original task, we substituted the 'number' category with the 'size' category as different number of objects required a higher resolution to be perceived and this slowed too much the simulations. For the same reason, we also substituted the form attributes 'stars' and 'crosses' with the attributes 'squares' and 'bars'. These changes did not alter the behaviour of the model and the comparisons with human behaviour.

Visual sensor. The visual sensor returns a 28 × 28 pixel RGB image covering a limited portion of the environment. The resulting 28 × 28 × 3 matrix is stored into a vector of 2, 352 elements that represents the input to the perceptual component. The visual sensor is displaced by the top-down processes (saccades). In particular, the sensor is first directed towards the deck-card and then is directed towards the target cards whom it scans in sequence until it finds a target card that matches the deck-card.

Perceptual component. This component is implemented as a deep generative model, in particular a Deep Belief Network (DBN; composed of two stacked Restricted Boltzmann Machines (RBM; Hinton, 2012). The main features of the component are considered here while a detailed description of its functioning and learning processes are presented in detail in the Supplementary Materials. A RBM is formed by two layers of units, a 'visible' layer, and a 'hidden' layer, linked by fully connected connections. A distinctive feature of RBM networks, and hence of the DBN, is that information can flow in both a bottom-up and a top-down fashion within it. While the bottom-up flow of the network -from the visible layer to the hidden layer-causes a dimensionality reduction of the input pattern , the top-down flow -from the hidden layer to the visible layer-produces a visible input. The capacity of the network to use an activation of the last hidden layer to produce, through a top-down information flow, the possible input that corresponds to such activation is an important property called generativity . This component was trained off-line through a novel algorithm (see Supplementary Materials) that allows the model to both extract the specific attributes of each card and to represent them in a distributed form. This allows the model to use generativity to simulate topdown attention processes. For example ( Figure 6) if a 'large, red, triangle' deck-card and a 'medium-large, red, square' target card are perceived, and the category selected at the higher levels is 'colour', the model can produce the activation of a red blob at the lower levels, for each card in sequence, and decide that the two cards match. In Section 3.3 we show that the bidirectional activation of the component involving the bottom-up abstraction and the top-down reconstruction can be repeated many times to simulate the activity reverberations of the visual working-memory and study a possible loss of information in the presence of interfering distractors if stimulus-response delays are introduced. Considering that in the WCST the participants can freely look at both the deck card and the table cards as many time as desired, we assume there is no loss of information to perform the visual matching process and we so fixed the number of repetitions to one (i.e. a single bottom-up activation spreading followed by a single top-down reconstruction).

Executive working-memory. The perceptual component is formed by three units encoding the three matching rules (colour, form, and size). The activation of each unit encodes the likelihood that the corresponding behavioural rule is selected. The units have in particular a continuous value ranging from 0 (low chance) to 1 (high chance) and store a sustained representation of the possible matching rules to use on the basis of a recurrent self-connection. The activation is fuelled by the feedback signal taking a binary value in {0, 1}. The feedback signal affects only the activation of the unit encoding the last selected and used rule as follows:
div.formula: m s,t = (1 − µ) • m s,t−1 + µ • r
div.p: (1) Figure 6: The architecture of the model highlighting the deep belief network for perception, the disinhibition mechanism for rule selection, and the rule values and softmax for the matching-rule selection. The figure shows a stimulus of the WCST at the bottom right: here the little square frames around the red triangle and the red square represent two 100 × 100 pixel images corresponding to a deck card and a target card collected by the system visual sensor in succeeding steps. The two analogous squared frames around the two red circles under the 'visual comparator' are the images resulting from the fact that the high-levels of the model are focusing on the category 'colour' and the attribute 'red' for comparing the two input cards.

where m s,t is the new activation of the rule unit, s ∈ {1, 2, 3} is the index of the selected rule, m s,t−1 is the previous activation of the unit, (1 − µ) is the strength of the unit recurrent connection, µ regulates the impact of the feedback on the memory, and r is the feedback signal that is equal to 1 in case of positive feedback (matching of the deck and target cards) and 0 otherwise. The parameter µ is set to a fixed value of 0.7 for positive feedback and to variable values for the negative feedback as the literature shows that this is a critical aspect for behavioural disengagement in the WCST . Such negative value of the parameter µ is in particular the first of the three key model parameters investigated in the simulations reported here. All the working-memory non-winning units decay exponentially towards a baseline value as follows:

where m l,t is the value related to the losing unit l (l ∈ {1, 2, 3}; l = s) at time t, 1 − φ is the strength of the recurrent connection, and α (set to 0.5) is the baseline value to which the memory unit activation converges. A high value of φ causes a high rate of information forgetting. The parameter φ is the second of the three key model parameters investigated here.

Perceptual manipulator. This component implements three processes. The first process is a winner-take-all (WTA) competition that receives the values from the working memory as input, and chooses the matching rule on the basis of a sof tmax function:
div.formula: P r(k = s) = exp(m k / τ ) 3 q=1 exp(m q / τ )(3)
div.p: where P r(k = s) is the probability that the event that the matching rule k (k ∈ {1, 2, 3}) is the one selected (k = s), τ is the 'temperature parameter' of the sof tmax function regulating the randomness of the selection. A high value of τ causes a high randomness/exploration of the behavioural rules. The parameter τ is the third of the three key model parameters investigated here. The probabilities P r(•), summing up to 1, are used to stochastically select the matching rule to use. The second process leads the winner unit of the WTA competition to disinhibit, through a double inhibition mechanism, the units of the last DBN hidden layer corresponding to the chosen category. The third process is a localistic winner-take-all mechanism (LWTA; , involving the units encoding the attributes of each category group, that is applied to the last DBN hidden layer before the dishinibition. Through this process, the unit having the maximum sigmoid activation (e.g. encoding 'red') is assigned an activation of 1, whereas the other units (e.g. encoding blue, green, and yellow) are assigned an activation of 0. This for example allows the activation of the attribute 'red' within the category 'colour'.

Visual comparator. This component computes the Euclidean distance between the two reconstructed images of the deck card and of the focused target card. Using a fixed threshold β (β = 0.1), the component returns a Boolean value representing the result of the comparison ('match'/'not match'). This process is an abstraction of neural comparison processes (e.g., see .

Motor component. This component encompasses two mechanisms. The first mechanism receives the position of the deck and target cards and brings the visual sensor (saccades) on them in a sequential manner. This captures the essence of more sophisticated attentional mechanisms that the model could use in future work, for example a bottom-up attention mechanism based on image salient areas or an inhibition-of-return mechanism , used in a previous paper .

The second mechanism of the motor component receives the position of the deck card and of the matched target card, and performs a movement bringing the deck card close to the matched target card. This action, here hard coded, is assumed to be learned by the system before the test (see .

div.head: Techniques used to analyse the model
div.p: We briefly mention here the techniques used to validate the model and analyse its behaviour and we expand their description in Supplementary Materials. The three key parameters of the model were searched through a brute-force search algorithms . The large number of models tested with this technique also allowed the performance of a sensitivity analysis of the found parameters , in particular to investigate how the variation of the best-fitting parameters affected the model accuracy. We also performed focused extreme alterations of the model key parameters, with respect to their ideal values, to mimic some of the brain impairments reviewed in Section 2.1. Finally, we computationally investigated the model core mechanism supporting the internal manipulation of representations by performing tests where the RBM visual working memory component reverberates to store information during stimulus-response delays in the presence of distractors.

div.head: Results
div.p: We organise the presentation of the results in three parts. In the first part we validate the model by showing how it can reproduce the behaviour of healthy and pathological humans in the WCST, and how it can furnish a sound interpretation of the possible brain processes underlying human behaviours and errors exhibited in the test performance. In the second part, we further validate the model by exploring the relation existing between the model behaviour and its key parameters. In particular, we show the results of a correlation analysis further investigating the link between the model parameters and the behavioural indices exhibited by humans in the WCST solution, and present the results of a 'lesion' experiment in which the key model parameters are altered by setting them to extreme values. Third, we analyse the internal functioning of the three key elements of the model mechanism for the internal manipulation of representations, highlighting its key role for the production of flexible behaviour. The behaviour, the 'reasoning processes', and the 'internal representations' of the model can be seen in action in this video: https://youtu.be/pnBWWqhULsE 3.1. Validation of the model with human data 3.1.1. Model configurations that best fit the data from healthy and pathological humans Table 1 shows the values of the model key parameters found with the automatic search method (µ: sensitivity to negative feedback errors; φ: working-memory forgetting speed; τ : exploration/distractibility) that best fit the target data. The 'pathological model' having parameters that best fit the data related to frontal patients from shows a lower µ, a higher φ, and a similar τ compared to the 'healthy model' that best fit the control participants from . This suggests that frontal patients: (a) are less flexible to adapt their behaviour after a negative feedback (µ); and (b) have a lower capacity to remember and reason about the behaviour to undertake based on experience (φ). These results agree with the literature proposing that frontal patients exhibit a mix of deficits involving the tendency to not consider contrary environmental feedback, and hence to persevere in non adaptive behaviours, and also to have a poor executive functioning involving working memory, behaviour monitoring, and reasoning (e.g., see .

Considering the data on Parkinson participants and the related control group , a first remarkable element emerging from Table 1, showing the parameters of the model that best fit the data, is that control participants have memory forgetting speed (φ) similar to the one of the frontal patient group of . This has an interesting explanation captured by the model: the frontal patient group had an average age of 42 ± 14.32 years whereas the Parkinson control group had an average age of 69.74 ± 6.96 years, so this latter group was probably affected by an aged-related weakening of the working memory . The parameters of the model that best fit the Parkinson data show a lower sensitivity to negative feedback (µ) with respect to the paired control group. This might be related to their altered capacity to process reward and feedback, a hallmark feature of the disease (deficits of the dopamine system also involve the capacity to process negative outcomes, aside positive ones, possibly due to the difficulty of processing reward prediction errors; . The comparison also shows a higher distractibility (τ ). This might be related to the Parkinson participants' lower capacity to 'lock-in' on correct behaviours once found, a relevant function of the dopamine system . Unexpectedly, the comparison also shows a low working-memory forgetting (φ), even if still higher than the one of younger healthy participants from the study of . This could be due to the effect of Parkinson treatments on the executive role of working memory that contributes to decision making, possibly affecting the reasoning-by-exclusion process involved in the WCST performance .

div.head: Error
div.p: Forgetting Table 1: Values of the parameters of the models that best fit the target WCST data related to the behavioural indices of healthy participants and frontal patients (data from , and of Parkinson controls and patients (data from .

The parameter search technique also allowed us to perform an analysis probing how the model fitting accuracy responds to the systematic variation of the three key model parameters. The results of such analysis for the frontal patients and the related healthy controls from , presented in detail in Supplementary Materials, indicate that: (a) healthy participants can be characterised by multiple alternative values of distractibility and sensitivity to choice errors where the two compensate (e.g., a high distractability goes with a high error sensitivity) and a variable forgetting rate; (b) instead, frontal patients tend to feature a stable low reactivity to errors and a medium distractibility, while again being robust to variable distractability. These results further validate the model capacity of furnishing an integrated interpretation of the target data.

div.head: WCST indices of the healthy and pathological models and corresponding human groups
div.p: In this section we further validate the model by showing the accuracy with which the model versions having the parameter configurations discussed in the previous section accurately reproduces the multiple behavioural indexes exhibited by the corresponding groups of human participants. For each model parameter set (human group), we compared 59 simulated participants (which differed for having different seeds of the random number generator) with the 59 frontal participants, and other 59 simulated participants with the 362 healthy participants, considered in . Figure 7 shows the average values of the indices of the healthy humans and of the model, while Figure 8 shows an analogous comparison for frontal patients. The comparisons show that the model reproduces with high accuracy the values of the WCST indexes of all the human groups considered. Table 2 presents the p-values of a statistical comparison between the behavioural indices of the models and those of the human groups. The indices are non statistically different (p > 0.05) with the exception of: CC, which is higher in the two models with respect to the human participants (healthy human versus healthy model: 5.18 ± 1.52 vs 5.9 ± 0.4, p < .01; pathological human versus pathological model: 3.46 ± 2.25 vs 4.6 ± 1.0, p < .01), and FMS, which is higher in the healthy model with respect to the humans (1.4 ± 1.3 versus 0.67 ± 1.09, p < .01). These differences are due to the very low variability of the model behaviour (see standard deviation in the figures) that causes a statistical disproportionate weight of small mean differences. Such lower variability of the model data is caused by the lower noise of its processes with respect to those of the human brain that can accomplish several functions and thus exhibits a higher variability in the WCST solution.

Regarding the experiments related to the Parkinson patients and the paired healthy control group reported in , most WCST indices of the model are non statistically different from those of the human groups. Again a statistical difference is present only for CC and FMS, higher for both models, for the same reasons considered above for the case of frontal patients. Overall, these results further show the capacity of the model to reproduce the multiple behaviours of the target human groups in great detail.
