div.head: Pathological humans
div.p: Pathological model 3.2. Study of the model internal functioning

div.head: Relation between the model key parameters and the WCST behavioural indices
div.p: In this section we analyse the relations between the three key model parameters and the WCST indices by considering their correlations as measured by the Pearson's r (Table 3) and a suitable visualisation able to indicate possible non-linear relations between them ( Figure S3 in Supplementray Materials). The analysis shows that the number of completed categories (index CC), indicating the model global performance, tends to be high with high error sensitivity (µ; r = +0.25), low forgetting (φ; r = −0.14), and low distractibility (τ ; r = −0.67). The analysis also indicates that the total number of errors (TE) has a negative link with the error sensitivity (µ; r = −0.60), and a positive one with distractibility (τ ; r = +0.34). This is coherent with the fact that a higher reactivity to feedback and a lower distractibility are expected to cause less errors in the task. The analysis further shows that perseverative errors (PE) have a robust negative link with negative feedback processing (µ; r = −0.58), in agreement with the classic literature on the WCST that associates perseverative rigid behaviours with a difficulty to adapt the behaviour following a negative feedback . The analysis additionally indicates that non-perseverative errors (NPE) have remarkable positive correlation with distractibility and erratic behaviours (τ ; r = +0.75) and a moderate correlation with forgetting (φ; r = +0.24), thus confirming the often-claimed relation between such type of errors and the lack of focus plus the failure to 'reason by exclusion' (based on the selection of the behavioural rule that have not yet been tried out, see . Interestingly, NPE negatively correlates with the sensitivity to negative feedback (µ; r = −0.26), suggesting that reasoning by exclusion strongly relies on the capacity to value feedback. Finally, the FMS shows a strong correlation with distractibility (τ ; r = +0.73), thus confirming that the difficulty to maintain a correct behaviour once found is strongly dependent on the capacity to keep the internal focus and commitment on the selected decision-making rule. Overall, these results agree with the literature (Section 2.1) and with the results obtained by different previous models (Section 4.2).

div.head: Effects of focused alterations of the model on the WCST behavioural indices
div.p: The simulated lesion technique allowed us to further investigate the role of each single key model parameter, and the related cognitive function and brain area, in the production of flexible behaviour measured by the WCST indices. In this respect, Section S4.3 and Figure S5 in Supplementary Materials show the possible correspondences between the three altered parameters, set to extreme values, and brain lesions. Table 4 in particular shows the three sets of parameters used to obtain the three versions of the model that we investigated. The first model, called the 'extreme perseverative model' (EPM) for ease of reference, is characterised by a very low value of µ. This alteration lowers the sensitivity to negative feedback following incorrect actions and might correspond to a malfunctioning of the ventral ACC involved in the motivational processing of errors . Such structure, in concert with medial and ventral cortical and subcortical areas, regulates negative emotions stimuli ). The second model, called 'distracted model' (DM), is characterised by a very high value of τ . This alteration might correspond to an impairment of the dorsal ACC that, by interacting with dorso-frontal cortices, is involved in decision-making and response selection ). The third model, called 'irrational model' (IM), is characterised by a high value of φ. This alteration causes the working-memory component to have a high forgetting rate for previously chosen rules and might correspond to an impairment of the brain system supporting executive working memory, in particular the dlPFC and its loops with basal ganglia . Table 4: Parameter values of the models impaired to produce focused alterations. Values in Italics represent the parameters that were altered with respect to the values found by fitting the healthy participants of .

A global view of the error proportions of the three altered models (Figure 9) confirms that the EPM (having low sensitivity to negative feedback) and the DM (having a highly variable decision making) have an opposite PE/NPE imbalance: the EPM has a high PE and low NPE; the DM has a low PE and high NPE. Moreover, the EPM has few FMS errors while the DM has many. The IM (having a high working-memory forgetting rate) shows slightly more errors then the healthy model, with an imbalance toward NPE mainly due to the impairment of the reasoning-by-exclusion process.

div.head: Analysis of the functioning of the model mechanism of internal representation manipulation
div.p: While the previous sections showed the high capacity of the model to match and account for the data on the behaviour of the WCST human participants, this section presents some results directed to show how the model behaviour depends on the processes implemented by the three core components instantiating the hypothesis proposed here, namely the executive working-memory, the top-down representation manipulator, and the visual working memory. To this purpose, we first study the relations between the activation of the executive working-memory units and the resulting model actions and errors in healthy and pathological conditions. Then we study the internal functioning of the model perceptual component, in particular showing how the top-down manipulator dynamically affects its internal representations of the input stimuli. Finally, we study the capacity of the top-down manipulator and the visual working memory to store relevant information in the presence of external time delays and distractors.

Executive working memory dynamics. To illustrate the functioning of the working memory component, we considered (a) the 'healthy model' (HM) and pathological model (PM) having the parameters found by fitting the data from (Figure 10), and (b) the three altered versions of the model Errors profiles of models with lesions compared to healthy model considered in the previous section, namely the extreme perseverative model (EPM), distracted model (DM), and irrational model (IM) ( Figure 11).

div.head: Healthy model (HM)
div.p: Pathological model (PM) Figure 10: Internal functioning of the executive working memory of the healthy model (HM) and the pathlogical model (PM). Each line represents the activation of a memory unit encoding a specific matching rule: thick red line: colour-based matching rule; dotted thin blue line: shape-based matching rule; continuous yellow line: size-based matching rule. The dots at the top of graphs indicate single instances of correct responses (CR) or errors (PE, NPE, FMS).

In the graphs, the parts of the curves rising from 0.5 to 1.0 during ten correct responses (CR) indicate a successfully completed card category. Curves decreasing from 1 to 0.5 indicate that the desirability of a matching rule decreases, possibly causing the selection of a different rule. Low values of two curves followed by the increase of the third curve indicate an inferential reasoning by exclusion. Sequences of several small peaks above the baseline (0.5) after a category change suggest a failure of such reasoning process. A stable horizontal curve coupled with many errors corresponds to a strong perseveration tendency (e.g., see the EPM graph). Conversely, a graph with several increments and decrements of different curves indicates an erratic behaviour (e.g., see the DM graph).

div.head: Extreme perseverative model (EPM)
div.p: Distracted model (DM) Irrational moddel (IM) Figure 11: Internal functioning of the executive working memory of the models with focused damages (EPM, DM, IM). Each line represents the activation of a memory unit encoding a specific matching rule: thick red line: colour-based matching rule; dotted thin blue line: shape-based matching rule; continuous yellow line: size-based matching rule. The dots at the top of graphs indicate the instances of correct responses (CR) or errors (PE, NPE, FMS).

The HM has an overall good performance (it completes the WCST six categories, Figure 10) and performs a correct reasoning after category changes, possibly after one or two errors and 'inference by exclusion'. Notice how even if this model corresponds to a 'healthy condition', it still exhibits exploratory behaviours that might sometimes look as pathological behaviours, e.g. in the choice interval 85−95. The PM ( Figure 10) exhibits both perseveration (e.g., see the many PE in the choice interval 15-25) and inefficient reasoning failures (e.g., many NPE in the choice interval 45-55). The PE are also exacerbated by a limitation of the Heaton's version of the WCST for which sometimes the deck and target cards have more than one attribute in common and this can produce a positive feedback notwithstanding the participant makes the selection based on a wrong matching rule ; e.g., this happens often in the choice interval 90-115).

The EPM ( Figure 11) shows a behaviour similar to the PM but characterised by a more severe insensitivity to feedback. This impairment causes a higher number of PE compared to the PM (e.g., see choice interval 65-115). The model is also more strongly affected by the WCST Heaton's version limitation indicated above than the PM. The DM ( Figure 11) shows an erratic behaviour caused by a severe impairment of the decision-making processes. The lowest values of its working-memory units are lower than those of the other models because this model often chooses a strategy that has already a low desirability. The IM ( Figure 11) exhibits a healthy behaviour but with a strong impairment of the capacity for reasoning by exclusion. In particular, the graph highlights that this deficit strongly affects the performance when the model should change the match rule but fails to do so, thus incurring in a PE or a NPE. Note that, as it happens in the experiments with human participants, the simulated experimenter (represented by a software routine that detects the errors) has no access to the model decision making processes. For this reason it might incorrectly score a distraction error as PE notwithstanding this is not due to a repeated intentional wrong rule selection but rather to an erratic decision process.

The rule-based activations of the model executive working memory appear qualitatively similar to those found in the neurons of the dlPFC during the solution of variants of WCST with non-human primates . These results and the model features support the idea that the storing capacities of the model working memory and its update could represent key processes for the internal manipulation of representations.

Perceptual component: internal representations. After training (see Supplementary Materials), the Deep Belief Network implementing the component is able to both extract the specific attributes of each card, at its higher level, and to generate images corresponding to such attributes, at the input-level. The latter capacity, used by the model to compare the WCST cards with respect to the selected category of attributes, is based on the generativity of the component. To investigate the quality of these representations, we analysed the images reconstructed by the component when single units from the first and second hidden layers of the network are manually activated in isolation. Figure 12 shows the images generated by activating the units of the first hidden layer (left graphs) or the units of the second hidden layer (right graphs). The figure shows that the images generated by the activation of single units of the first hidden layer involve different attributes of categories (e.g, mixed colours, forms, sizes). Instead, the images obtained by activating the single units of the second hidden layer involve disentangled representations of a specific category attribute independently of the other attributes. For example, a unit produces the 'prototype' of the blue colour independently of the object size and shape, and another unit produces the prototype of the 'triangle' shape independently of the object colour and size.

The presence of different internal representations at different levels of abstraction within the first and second hidden layer reflect what also happens in brain. For example, the neurons of the primary visual cortex extract several low-level visual features from the retina images whereas the neurons of the higher-order visual cortices tend to respond to macro-aspects of objects . Although not further investigated here with the model, these different representations could be used by brain to flexibly carry out different tasks requiring representations of precepts at a different levels of abstraction. Figure 12: Left: Images generated by activating a sample of single neurons of the first hidden layer, showing how each encodes a mixture of colour, shape, and size attributes. Right: Images generated by activating single neurons of the second hidden layer, showing how each encodes a specific disentangled category attribute. This can be seen by considering that the three rows of graphs refer to the three categories (from top to bottom: colour, form, size) and the four columns refer to different category attributes (colour: yellow, red, blue, green; form: bar, triangle, circle, square; size: small, medium-small, medium-large, large).

Dynamics of the manipulator and visual working memory. Here we illustrate the results of the tests of the top-down manipulator and the perceptual component working as visual working memory. In particular, we analyse the time-dependent loss of information of the visual working memory about an initial image while the system is disturbed by distractors. This is particular measured on the basis of a 'correctness index' measuring the probability of retaining and representing an initially perceived image in the presence of distrators (see Supplementary Materials for details). Figure 13 shows the results of the tests corresponding to a different number of resonance cycles (d ∈ {10, 100, 1000, 10000}) and different levels of focused retention (ζ; a value ζ = 1 implies that the DBN is fully focused on the input memory, ζ = 0 means that it is fully driven by the distractor, and ζ = 0.5 means the it assigns the same wight to the memory and to the distractor).

The figure shows that the simulation with ζ = 0, performing a reconstruction that exclusively depends on the distractor, exhibits a probability of 75% to generate an incorrect reconstruction (due to the fact that 1 time out of 4 the attribute of the distractor reconstructed by the component matches the attribute of the initial image to be remembered by chance). Instead, when the network fully focuses on the image to be remembered (ζ = 1) the reconstruction error is null. This contrasts the behaviour of classical DBM networks that exhibit a progressive lost of the original information after multiple reverberation cycles , similarly to what happens in the case of distraction and 'mind-wandering' . The reason is that the top-down manipulator biases the activation of the DBN during the reverberations so that these remain locked into a stable attractor corresponding to the information to be remembered, akin to focused attention. This shows that the representation internal manipulation mechanism is capable of selecting a desired representation with high level of stability. With intermediate values of focus (0 < ζ < 1), the system exhibits a loss of information that gets more severe with the increase of time delay/number of perceived distractors. Overall, the results show the importance of the categorybased top-down manipulation of representations to preserve task relevant representations in the presence of additional external patterns.

div.head: Proposal of a modified WCST to study the manipulation of visual working memory contents
div.p: The test on time delays and distractors suggests the formulation of a possible computer-based variant of the WCST that would allow a more direct test of the hypothesis proposed here for which the manipulation of internal representations is at the basis of cognitive flexibility. The proposed new test integrates into the WCST experimental protocol some elements of the protocols used to investigate the effects of delays and interfering stimuli on perceptual working memory . Figure 14 shows the key phases of the new experimental protocol: (a) the participant presses one of three buttons to manifest the sorting rule that s/he intends to use; other manipulations are possible, for example the rule might be externally indicated to the participant, etc.; (b) the deck-card is displayed for a certain time: the display time might be shortened to augment the interference of the following distractors; (c) one or more distractors are displayed during the stimulus-response delay: distractors might be formed by randomly selected cards, blank inputs, or other items, and the delay might be set to different lengths to challenge the memory in different ways; (d) the participant is shown the target cards and has to choose one of them by pressing one of four buttons. These features of the protocol have the following rationale: (a) the initial declaration of the rule to use allows the study of how it affects the top-down control of the visual memory; (b) the deck-card is the stimulus from which the participant extracts the visual attribute to remember: the correct one is known by the computer-program because of point'a'; (c) the manipulation of the delay duration and typology of distractors allows the manipulation of the interference with the working memory; (d) the participant's response can be analysed quantitatively: for example the test allow one not only to score the classic WCST errors, but also memory 'retention errors' and response times. Possible additional factors could be studied, for example by introducing a verbal shadowing mechanism to evaluate the support of the executive working memory by inner verbal rehearsal mechanisms .

The protocol could allow the test of our hypothesis, in particular to ascertain the presence of a top-down bias manipulating the representations within the visual working memory versus the alternative hypothesis for which all processes to solve the WCST take place at the high level as proposed by previous models and theories. For example, one might manipulate distractors in ways that tend to change the representations at the low level but not at the high level, and measure as a consequence different retention errors and/or reaction times. For example, the participant might choose the 'shape' rule, implying the selection of a specific attribute of the deck card, say the 'circle' of a 'small red circle' card, and then the computer might present either 'reinforcing distractors', say cards as the deck card, or 'interfering distractors', say cards with 'medium-small/medium-large/large blu/green/yellow circles'. The latter distractors should interfere with the visual working memory (that encodes also non-relevant features) but not with the central executive working memory (that encodes the attribute 'circle' in a disentangled way) and thus produce different retention errors and/or reaction times. This is just a preliminary idea to be refined and other manipulations could be thought in order to produce measurable differential effects on the visual working memory and the executive working memory. Brain imaging techniques could also be used to investigate the different involvement of low-level visual working memories to perform tasks requiring a different engagement of the executive working memory and the visual working memory.

div.head: Discussion of the main contributions
div.p: The novel hypothesis we proposed here states that flexible cognition relies on the top-down manipulation of internal low-level perceptual representations. These representations can then support a suitable sensorymotor interaction with the environment leading to the solution of the task. The hypothesis agrees with the empirical evidence on the brain showing how imagination processes involve low-level cortical areas . Moreover, it is also corroborated by the fact that prefrontal cortex is strongly connected with parietal cortex, in turn forming highly integrated sub-systems with motor areas ; functionally, these systems play an important role in representing 'affordances', encoding the conditions in which actions can be successfully executed , and play a key role in the online control of action movements . The hypothesis, operationalised in a computational model, diverges from previous proposals incorporated in models of cognitive flexibility and the WCST, considered in detailed in the following section, that directly link the selection of behavioural rules to the selection of actions rather than to the manipulation of lower-level representations.

The computational model represents a new tool for the quantitative study of the proposed hypothesis. This possibility has been shown here by validating the model with data from multiple WCST experiments, run both with healthy participants and frontal/Parkinson patients, often reproduced in isolation in previous models (Table 2 and Figure 8). For example, the model confirmed the key role of error sensitivity for the production of perseverative errors and the key role of distractibility for the production of non-perseverative errors. The capacity of the model to reproduce and explain these errors and other behavioural indices was also shown with a correlation analysis (Table 3) and by lesioning key parameters of the model (Table 4 and Figure 9). In addition, a qualitative analysis of the activation of the executive working memory of the model (Figure 11) highlighted the different possible causes of non-perseverative errors. In particular, the analysis corroborated the theoretical proposals of some studies suggesting that non-perseverative errors could be caused by an impairment of working memory, an impairment of reasoning processes, or attentional failures (distractions).

The core mechanism of the model allows the behavioural rule selected within the high-level executive working memory to exert a top-down bias on the lower perceptual levels of the model to generate representations of the input reflecting the selected rule. A qualitative analysis of the internal representations of the model executive working memory and perceptual areas showed the key role that such internal manipulation process can play for flexible behaviour, in particular by allowing the system to 'see reality' (e.g., the cards) in a 'rule-biased way' suitable to carry out the task (Figures 10 and 11). The activation of the model units at high and low levels are compatible with those found in the prefrontal cortex during the solution of the WCST and in the visual extrastriate cortices in categorisation tasks .

Additional tests of the model not yet corresponding to specific empirical experiments also showed, in line with what happens in the brain , that the model perceptual areas can work as perceptual working memory. This allowed us to test more in depth the core, mechanism of the model based on the executive-working-memory top-down bias by measuring how it is able to protect the contents of the perceptual areas from spontaneous drifts in time, and from distractors ( Figure 13). The results showed how the top-down bias might have different strengths, now regulated externally, to tune the mixing of the top-down generated images and new incoming information. In the tests run here such additional information represents 'distractors' but in other tasks it might be relevant to integrate such information with previous stimuli.

The latter tests also supported the proposal of a variant of the WCST (Figure 14) that might allow a more direct empirical evaluation of the proposed hypothesis. The new test in particular aims to create the conditions for which a mere selection of behavioural rules at the abstract high-level executive working memory is not enough to support the solution of a task and requires also the activation of lower-level perceptual areas to recover relevant details of the stimuli. This would ensure that in such conditions the core mechanism hypothesised here is actually operating, thus paving the way to a focused study of its features.

div.head: Comparison with other models of the WCST
div.p: In this section we compare the model presented here with other models proposed to study the cognitive processes and neural mechanisms underlying the solution of the WCST. A main outcome of this analysis is that no previous model has linked the selection of categories and attributes underlying the solution of the WCST to the manipulation of perceptual representations within low-level perceptual areas. A secondary outcome of this analysis, relevant to validate the model and hence the hypothesis proposed here, is that no previous model presented an account of different human groups' performance and behavioural indices as comprehensive as the one presented here (but some models tackled aspects not considered here, e.g. the WCST performance of schizophrenic patients, , or patients with substance addition, . proposed a seminal model of the WCST that incorporates a mechanism at the molecular level that supports reward processing and synaptic plasticity. The model is based on an architecture encompassing the selection of rules and their integration with percepts in order to select actions. The model was tested for its capacity to reproduce perseverative errors. proposed a model that simulates neural noise and synaptic instability based on two parameters, 'noise' and 'gain', and linked these to the poor WCST performance of schizophrenic patients. The model considers attention processes related to the competition between categories but it does not investigate their relation with perceptual working memory. The model reproduces perseverative and non-perseverative errors in normal and schizophrenic participants but it does not reproduce and account for failure-to-maintain errors. reproduced the WCST with a model using a Hamming network (a feed-forward neural network solving pattern recognition problems; to generate new strategies, and a Hopfield model (an associative neural network; to store them. These networks are used to reproduce both perseverative and failure-to-maintain errors, proposing that the first are caused by rigidity and the second by attention failures. The model does not consider non-perseverative errors and reproduces the WCST as a 'rule selection task' without considering visual working memory and matching mechanisms.

Various versions of the model were tested by changing two parameters, the Hopfield threshold and the Hamming distance, but they were not compared with different healthy and pathological human groups. proposed a model that solves the WCST and investigates the cognitive profile of patients with a substance addiction. The model encompasses an abstract component computing positive feedback, negative feedback, and a 'choice consistence' (attention focus), and also two different parameters regulating the sensitivity to negative and positive feedback based on the neuroscientific literature showing a dissociation between the two . Despite this evidence, apply the model to the study of Parkinson patients and find, in agreement with what seen here, that the response to negative feedback is sufficient to fit their performance. proposed a recurrent neural network that shows a rule selectivity in a WCST involving only 'form' and 'colour' categories. The model reproduces internal neuronal dynamics that involve mixed selectivity neurons, suggesting that randomly connected neurons spontaneously exhibit mixed selectivity. The model does not propose an architecture to solve the WCST but rather it focuses on the internal processes needed to solve context-dependent tasks with the purpose of investigating how integrated neural networks can support the selection and storage of behavioural strategies. proposed a computational model that operationalises the 'schema theory' proposed by on the basis of a model architecture based on the neuroanatomy of basal-ganglia. The work focuses only on perseverative and failure-to-maintain errors and accounts only for the behaviour of a healthy human group. The work underlines the important function played by basal ganglia, a fundamental 'selection machine' in the brain , a function also incorporated in the model presented here.

The models considered this far highlight the cognitive processes supporting the solution of the WCST in healthy and pathological participants. Another set of models focus on mimicking the PFC learning mechanisms supporting various working memory functions. One of these models, presented by , is used to reproduce the results of the WCST and has features shared with the other models of this type. The model, implemented withing the framework called 'Leabra' , is in particular formed by various neural maps corresponding to input layers, parietal cortices, prefrontal cortices, and motor output layers. The model is tested with the WCST and simulates the production of perseverative errors when the PFC layer is lesioned, but it does not consider other types of errors. Another model of the set (the 'PBWM model'), proposed by O'Reilly and , simulates various functions of working memory by using an actor-critic model architecture to reproduce the functions and macro-anatomy of the basal-ganglia. The model is in particular used to show the role of 'gating units' possibly used by basal ganglia to perform the upload, storing, and download of information in working memory. propose an evolution of the previous model implementing other functions of basal ganglia to make the gating process suitable to solve different tasks. Finally, propose a comparison of the different variants of the PBWM model and also propose the implementation of 'indirection processes' that the brain might possibly use to execute symbolic processing.

At last, 'COVIS', proposed by , represents both a theoretical framework and a computational implementation of neural structures supporting category-learning processes. The model is based on a hybridisation of symbolic and sub-symbolic mechanisms and is grounded on the idea that brain performs category learning through a procedural implicit system, mostly involving sub-cortical structures such as basal ganglia, and a logical explicit system, mostly involving cortical areas. The model reproduces the WCST data collected from healthy participants and Parkinson patients , highlighting the role of dopamine shortage in the executive deficits exhibited by Parkinson patients.

This analysis shows that these models are based on the direct sequence of processes, highlighted in Figure 4, involving 'rule-decision, selection of sub-goal, and action performance'. Instead, our hypothesis and model posit that the high-level decision making processes do not directly select action but rather manipulate 'backward' the internal low-level representations of stimuli that then trigger the execution of the correct actions. These processes are also supported by interactive sensorimotor loops with the environment allowing the system to compare the low-level perceptual representations of stimuli, suitably manipulated by the high-level decision making processes on the basis of the pursued goal and sub-goals.

div.head: Conclusions and future work
div.p: In this work we proposed a new hypothesis to explain flexible cognition as manifested by human participants engaged in the solution of the Wisconsin Card Sorting Test (WCST). The hypothesis posits that flexible cognition relies on goal-directed processes that manipulate low-level perceptual representations that in turn support the production of suitable actions. This hypothesis is novel with respect to previous proposals and models of the WCST as these are all based on decision making mechanisms directly supporting action selection.

The hypothesis has been operationalised through the proposal of a computational model. The model relies on three main processes that we propose to be supported by specific brain systems. The first process involves the executive working memory, relying on the brain prefrontal cortex and ventro-medial basal ganglia, that stores goals and behavioural rules. The second process involves perceptual working memories, relying on the hierarchies of perceptual cortical systems, able to extract and retain information at different levels of abstraction. The third process involves the internal manipulation of perceptual representations, relying on the brain system formed by fronto-parietal cortices and the underlying dorso-medial basal ganglia, that selects the representations in the perceptual working memory on the basis of the activation of the executive working memory. We validated the model by showing how it can reproduce and account for a large set of behavioural indices and data related to healthy and pathological participants of the WCST to an extent that goes beyond what done individually by each previous model.

We also used the proposed model as a basis to propose a modified version of the WCST that would allow a more direct test of the proposed hypothesis. In particular, the new test could allow the manipulation of stimuli in ways that would affect the low-level visual working memory contents but not the high-level executive working memory, thus showing that the manipulation of such low-level contents indeed supports flexible cognition.

div.head: Limitations and future directions
div.p: Notwithstanding the contributions highlighted in the previous section, the model currently has some limitations that might be faced in future work. A relevant aspect of the architecture to improve regards the information flow between the model components. A general strategy to use to this purpose could be to use deep neural networks as done for the visual component (see , for this strategy). Another possibly complementary strategy could be to ground the information flows of the model on an architecture mimicking the macro-structure of the relevant brain components (e.g., as done in .

Regarding the model components, a first limitation involves the simplicity of the executive working memory component, now formed by few neural units encoding the possible matching rules. This component might be improved by using mechanisms employed in other models of working memory, thus improving the biological plausibility of the model (e.g., O'Reilly and , or in deep neural networks (e.g., .

Another component of the model that might be enhanced is the overt attentional system, now relying only on a bottom-up attention process leading the model to explore all stimuli in a stereotyped sequential way. Although sufficient to study the WCST, this component might be improved with the addition of a topdown attention process for the goal-directed exploration of the elements in the environment, thus improving the embodiment of the model and allowing it to solve other tasks (e.g., see .

Another important aspect of the model to enhance is the process it employs to acquire category and attribute representations. Now the model uses a supervised learning algorithm, where the supervision comes from a non-specified external mechanism, for example other agents. Social learning might be important for the acquisition of categories, but we think that in humans most category learning derives from direct experiences in the environment. In the future, we thus aim to employ other algorithms, in particular reinforcement learning algorithms , to support the model autonomous learning of categories based on the feedback from the environment following the performance of actions. To this purpose, the embodied nature of the model supporting a direct interaction with the environment would be crucial, for example the model might acquire categories and attributes through the solution of multiple tasks. This might allow the use of the model to face other neuro-psychological tasks.

A final improvement involves the key mechanism of the model related to the internal manipulation of representations. Now this mechanism operates only on the highest level of the Deep Belief Network used to implement the visual hierarchy. In this respect, an important enhancement of the model would be a manipulator operating at multiple levels of abstraction of the hierarchy rather than only at one. This would allow the model to directly manipulate representations having different levels of detail as needed by downstream processes. For example, the manipulator could focus not only on object attributes (e.g., 'circular shape') but also on their lower-level features (e.g., different edges and corners of shapes) or on the relations between objects forming a scene (the latter would require the addition of more abstract layers to the model); similarly it could focus on sub-goals forming overall goals; on the single actions forming the action sequences needed to pursue goals; or on the predictions related to the consequences of actions.

We think that, if suitably developed in these ways, the model could show how the mechanism for the manipulation of internal representations proposed here might indeed be behind the multifaceted manifestations of the cognitive flexibility exhibited by humans.

div.head: Acknowledgements
div.p: The bottom-up and top-down activation of the DBN works as follows. The activation potential p j of the unit j of a receiving layer of the network is computed as:
div.formula: p j = i w ji • x i (4)
div.p: where x i is the activation of a unit i of the sending layer and w ji is a connection weight linking the two units used for both the bottom-up and the top-down information flow. As we shall see below, in some moments of the network functioning the activation of a unit, x j , is computed on the basis of a continuous sigmoid transfer function f [•]:
where:
In other moments, discussed below, the activation potential of a unit is used to determine its binary activation on the basis of a stochastic process:
div.formula: x j = 0 if n ≥ f [p j ] 1 if n < f [p j ](7)
div.p: where n is a random number sampled in (0, 1) with a uniform distribution.

During the solution of WCST, the bottom-up information flow (perception) starts with the activation of the visible layer, proceeds with the first hidden layer sigmoid activation, and terminates with the second hidden layer sigmoid activation. The top-down DBN information flow, based on the generative nature of the two piled RBMs forming the DBN, starts with the activation of the second hidden layer. The units within this layer, receiving the bias from the top-down manipulator, assume a binary value in {0, 1} to encode one attribute for the selected category. The top-down information flow continues with the activation of the first hidden layer and terminates with the activation of the visible layer.

div.head: Training of the perceptual component
div.p: This section illustrates the learning processes of the DBN that, as in human participants, take place before performing the WCST. These processes are as follows: (a) the first RBM of the DBN acquires an internal representation of the low-level features of the input pattern from the cards through contrastive divergence , the standard unsupervised learning algorithm of RBMs; (b) the second RBM learns the category attributes of cards through a supervised learning algorithm: this algorithm uses constrastive divergence but substitutes the spontaneous firing of the 'hidden' units of such rule with a suitable desired activation pattern. To the best of our knowledge, the latter algorithm is novel (cf. . We now consider these learning processes more in detail.

For a given card image d (d ∈ D = {1, 2, . . . , 64}, where D are the indexes of the different cards) the connection weights w ji of the first RBM, linking a unit i of the visible unit layer (2352 units) and unit j of the first hidden layer (150 units), are updated as follows:
div.formula: ∆ d w ji = η • (v • h − v • h )(8)
div.p: where ∆ d w ji is the update of the connection weight, η is a learning rate (η = 0.01), v is the activation of the visible unit due to the input pattern, h is the stochastic activation of the hidden unit computed on the basis of the activation of the visible units, v is the 'reconstructed input', i.e. the sigmoidal activation of the visible unit caused by the stochastic activation of the hidden units, h is a sigmoidal activation of the hidden units caused by the reconstructed input. Intuitively, the algorithm updates the connection weights to minimize the difference ('constrast') between the activation of the hidden units following the initial input activation, and their 'spontaneous' activation caused by the reconstructed input ('spontaneous' as the reconstructed input is caused by a sample of the first stochastic activation of the hidden units). The update of each connection weight is done in a batch way by summing up the effects of the updates related to all D cards:
div.formula: ∆ b w ji = D d ∆ d w ji + δ • ∆ b−1 w ji (9)
div.p: where b indicates the batch index (multiple successive batches are performed during learning) and δ is a coefficient of the momentum mechanism used to speed up learning (δ = 0.9). The second RBM is formed by the the first DBN hidden layer (150 units, now playing the role of 'visible units') and the second DBN hidden layer (12 units, playing the role of 'hidden units'; η was set to a higher value, 0.1, with respect to the first RBM given its lower number of units). The new supervised learning algorithm was implemented by substituting the stochastic activation of the hidden layer of the RBM with desired values from {0, 1} representing the actual attributes of the input image, for example 'red', 'circle', 'small'. This is the only change with respect to the unsupervised-learning constrastive divergence algorithm, so the formulas presented above were also used here. The effect of this update is that the input pattern tends to cause the desired output pattern (correct attributes) at the level of the second RBM hidden layer (this is the more abstract representation of the DBM). Biologically, these learning processes abstract the acquisition of the representations of different classes thorough the performance of multiple tasks under the guidance of rewards/punishments following actions. Figure S1 shows the reconstruction error during the training of the two RBMs. The error was computed as:

where v is the original input vector, v is the reconstructed input vector, || • || 1 is the L1 norm, and |D| (|D| = 64) is the number of the input images (cards) and also of the size of the learning 'batch' used to train the component. For the second RBM, the graph in the figure also shows the number of cards (out of 64) whose attributes were correctly identified by the DBN. The graphs show that the first RBM achieved a reconstruction error of 0.005 after 37.000 batches while the second RBM achieved a reconstruction error of 0.1 after 130 batches showing a high efficiency of the supervised learning process used here.

1st RBM 2nd RBM Figure S1: Learning process of the two RBMs forming the perceptual component. Left: first RBM, moving average over 300 learning batches of the reconstruction error. Right: second RBM, reconstruction error and number of cards whose attributes were correctly classified by the RBM (and DBN).

To directly evaluate the quality of the training outcome, Figure S2 shows the capacity of the two RBMs to reconstruct the image at the level of the DBN input layer thanks to their generative nature. To test the capability of the first RBM, we performed an input→hidden1→input sigmoid-based activation spreading: the first input activation produced a distributed internal representation at the level of the first hidden layer ('hidden causes' of the input), and then the resulting hidden activation pattern was used to reconstruct the input with a backward activation spreading. To test the whole DBN, the input reconstruction was done through an input→hidden1→hidden2→hidden1→input activation spreading (activation of hidden layer 1 was based on the sigmoid function; the activation of hidden layer 2 was based on the hardmax function extracting the attributes of the image, e.g. 'green, big, circle'). The figures show that the input reconstructions performed by the first RBM are more accurate than those generated by the whole DBN due to the stronger abstraction performed by the DBN hidden layer 2 compared to the DBN hidden layer 1. The quality of the images based on the DBN hidden layer 2 is however still sufficient to support an effective comparisons of cards. Methods: further details on the model parameter search and model validation Estimation of the model key parameters Some of the model parameters are very important to determine the overall behaviour of the model exhibited in the solution of the WCST, so it was important to systematically search and test them. These parameters were: µ: sensitivity to negative feedback errors; φ: working-memory forgetting speed; τ : exploration/distractibility. The parameter search technique used allowed us to fit the data of different groups of participants of the WCST (healthy humans, frontal patients, and Parkinson patients) and on this basis to characterise some of the cognitive processes underlying their behaviour, in particular the different types of errors exhibited while solving the task.

The parameters were estimated in particular by using a brute force search algorithm directed to minimise the difference between the WCST indices obtained by the model and those of humans. The estimated parameters had the following ranges: φ ∈ (0.0, 1.0); µ ∈ (0.0, 1.0); τ ∈ (0.0, 0.3). To apply the algorithm we divided each parameter range in 10 equally separated values, thus in total we had 10 3 = 1, 000 combinations of parameters. For each parameter combination we ran 30 repeated simulations over which we computed the average values of the WCST indices. These average values were compared with the average of a given target human group to select the parameter set that gave the best fit. The comparison was based on the Mean Squared Error (MSE) computed as follows:
where y is the vector of mean indices of the human group, y is the vector of mean indices of the model, || • || 2 is the L2 norm, and n is the length of the vectors.

We applied this procedure to human data related to healthy participants and frontal patients presented in ; these data are paired for age, education level, and IQ for the two groups. The healthy group was formed by 356 participants and the pathological group by 59 patients having a local or diffused frontal lesion. To further validate the model, we also applied the procedure to data related to Parkinson patients and control participants presented in ; these data are paired for age, education, and cognitive decline (Dementia Rating Scale).

The large set of parameters tested also allowed us to run a sensitivity analysis . This was in particular directed to investigate how the MSE of different groups of human participants, and their behavioural indices, responded to a systematic variation of the model key parameters.

div.head: Focused damages of the model key processes
div.p: To study the role of the model parameters in depth, we executed alterations of one of the three key model parameters while leaving the other two parameters set to the values found by fitting the healthy participants of . These tests allow a clear identification of the causal relation between the cognitive aspects affected by each parameter and the WCST indices. Figure S3 shows the functional architecture of the system highlighting the locus of the impairment, the possible corresponding sites in brain, and the overall effects produced. The methodology used is akin to the classical 'lesion approach' often used in bio-constrained models. This classic approach was not applicable to our model because the lesion of its key areas (the working memory, manipulator, and motivational components) impaired the model behaviour too strongly. Instead, the alteration of the model key parameters allow a partial damage of the model functioning. Figure S3: This schema shows the model architecture and three 'focused lesions', obtained through specific parameter alterations, that we applied to obtain three prototypical pathological conditions. Dots with a different grey intensity represent the three alterations ('lesions') while the coloured bolts summarise the decrease of performance/increase of errors that they cause in the WCST performance. For example lesion I, mimicking effects analogous to those produced by a brain lesion of ventral ACC and vmPFC and impairing the motivation system, cause a decrease of CC and an increase of TE and PE.

div.head: Test of the manipulator and visual-working memory
div.p: We now illustrate in detail the procedure used to study the retention capacity of the model visual working memory component in the presence of time delays and interfering distractors. The analysis of this aspect of the model allows us to show the functioning of the model key mechanism for the manipulation of internal representations. This test is needed as the WCST protocol allows the participants to freely look at the deck card and the target cards multiple times and so it does not allow to probe the presence of top-down generative representations as these mix with the continuous input. The new test also suggested a new variant of the WCST paradigm, illustrated in the Section 'Discussion' of the main article, that might be used to more directly investigate the mechanism.

Cognitive neuroscience literature defines working memory as a storing system that can maintain information for a limited time window and allows the manipulation of such information for the preparation of behaviour . The computational literature offers many examples of working-memory models . These models are able to store input information, usually encoded in an abstract form, either in a 'localistic way' (a single neural unit encodes a single input pattern) or in a 'sparse way' (many units encode a single input pattern). In all cases, these models maintain an abstract representation of the input or internal patterns feeding them but are not able to reproduce those patterns as it can be done by the model presented here thanks to the generative capabilities of the DBN. The test we propose draws from the literature on perceptual working memory showing that the retention capacity of visual features depends on both the time delays and interfering stimuli . However, the test has also a novel feature that allows the study of the effects of the top-down bias on the memory dynamics.

As we have seen above, the DBN used here to implement the model perceptual component can support a bidirectional flow of information from the input layers to the hidden layers and vice versa for multiple cycles. This reverberation process, called 'Gibbs sampling' , is at the core of the learning algorithm used by the network. The reverberation allows the simulation of a dynamic working memory that stores information for a certain time window. The reverberation process can also be influenced by the bias of the model manipulator that can force a specific activation (e.g., a certain category and attribute) within the visual working memory. This process is particularly interesting as the spontaneous reverberation of the DBN leads it to explore different patterns in time , similarly to 'mind wandering'. Moreover, if the input units of the network are activated by additional distracting patterns after the presentation of a relevant input pattern to be remembered, the network reverberation will also tend to encode a mixed representation of the two, thus allowing the simulation of interference. In this case, the manipulator bias might lead the memory to not only focus on the features of interest of the relevant input, but also to have a more stable dynamics in the presence of the internal drift tendency and the external distractors, an effect that can be studied with the test we now illustrate more in detail.

The DBN component was presented an input card to be remembered for a certain amount of time, corresponding to a certain number of reverberation cycles. We define a 'reverberation cycle' as the bottomup information spreading followed by the top-down manipulator-biased information spreading leading to form a reconstructed input pattern; this pattern feeds the next reverberation cycle. Distractors are presented as follows. During each reverberation cycle we present the visual working memory a distracting input pattern (a card randomly chosen from the deck) by adding it to the reconstructed input; the resulting mixed pattern is used by the DBN for the next reverberation cycle. The mixing pattern was in particular obtained by activating each DBN input unit as follows:

where x t is the input unit at reverberation cycle t (t = 0, 1, ..., n with n representing the total number of reverberation cycles), x t−1 is the reconstructed input produced by the previous reverberation cycle (at t = 0 the component receives only the relevant card input without the distractor), ζ is an important retention parameter regulating the model capacity to maintain a memory of the target card, and d t is the distractor pixel activating the input unit.

The test was repeated, using an already trained DBN, with different time delays (i.e., different number of reverberation cycles: n ∈ {10, 100, 1000, 10000}) and different values of the retention parameter (ζ ∈ {0, 0.2, 0.5, 0.8, 1}). For each combination of the two parameters, we ran 12 different 'trials' of the test in each of which the top-down manipulator was set to select one specific attribute (out of 4) of one specific category (out of 3) while the system was presented a card having that category and attribute. Each of this trials was repeated for 30 times with different seeds of the random number generator. For each combination of parameters, we measured the proportion ('correctness index') of repetitions where the DBN was able to give, at the end of the time delay, a reconstructed input equal to the one of the first reverberation cycle of the trial: the reconstructed input of the first reverberation cycle is not affected by the memory shift and the distractors, so it represents the correct reconstruction that the component should produce if it manages to retain the desired input feature.

div.head: Sensitivity analysis results
div.p: In this section we present the results of the sensitivity analysis directed to evaluate how the key model parameters affect the MSE related to the data of the healthy and frontal pathological participants of . Recall that the key parameters involved in these studies have this meaning: µ: sensitivity to negative feedback errors; φ: working-memory forgetting speed; τ : exploration/distractibility. Figure S4 shows the MSE of the tested combinations of parameter values. The simulated healthy participants have a low MSE (indicating a high accuracy of the model data fitting) for various combinations of the parameter values. These involve either low values for both the error sensitivity (µ) and distractibility (τ ), or medium-high values for both, while the forgetting parameter (φ) can assume different values. This might indicate that a higher distractibility can be compensated for by a higher sensitivity to choice errors. The fitting of data related to frontal patients shows a lower number of parameter sets that produce a low MSE, in particular requiring a low reactivity to negative feedback (µ) and medium distractibility (τ ); instead, the model is more robust to the variability of the forgetting parameter (φ) as for the case of healthy participants.

div.head: MSE (target = healthy humans)
div.p: MSE (target = pathological humans) Figure S4: Mean Squared Error (MSE) of the combinations of the three searched parameters (x, y, and z axes), in the case of healthy humans (left graph) and pathological humans (right graph). Red spheres represent low values of MSE, hence a behaviour of the model close to the one of the target group, while yellow spheres represent high values.

The sensitivity analysis also allowed the evaluation of how the behavioural of the healthy group varied in correspondence to a systematic variation of the three key model parameters. Figure S5 shows in particular 3D plots indicating the relation between the model three key parameters and each of the WCST behavioural indexes. The ellipses overimposed to the graphs indicate the areas of the parameter space that produce high values of the considered index. Overall the graphs confirm the correlation analysis presented in the main text. Failures-to-maintain sets (FMS) Figure S5: Relation between the model three key parameters and the WCST behavioural indexes. Blue dots indicate low values of the indices whereas red dots indicate high values.

Behavioural indices of the model with focused damages: statistical comparisons The main text presented a comparison of the behavioural indices of three models each obtained by setting one of the three key model parameters to an extreme value while setting the remaining two to the values obtained by fitting the data of the healthy participants from . The three models were in particular as follows: (1) 'Extreme perseverative model' (EPM): very low value of µ lowering the sensitivity to negative feedback following incorrect actions; (2) 'Distracted model' (DM): very high value of τ involving an erratic decision making process; (3) 'Irrational model' (IM): high value of φ implying a high forgetting rate for previously chosen rules. The main text presents an overview of how the indices of the three models are in comparison to those of the healthy model (HM). Here we integrate such analysis by giving further details on such comparison ( Figure S6).

With respect to the HM, the EPM, characterised by a low sensitivity to negative errors (low µ), has a lower CC index (1.9 ± 0.9 vs. 5.9 ± 0.4, p < .001), and a higher TE index (74.5 ± 10.1 vs. 23.4 ± 5.5, p < .001) caused by a high number of PE (63.0 ± 11.8 vs. 12.4 ± 3.8, p < .001) while the number of NPE is not statistically different (11.5 ± 5.8 vs. 11.0 ± 4.2, p > .05). The EPM incurs in fewer FMS errors compared to the healthy model (0.5 ± 0.7 vs. 1.4 ± 1.3, p < .001). This is due to the extreme perseverative behaviour which causes a high level of PE (85% of total errors) but also prevents it to mistakenly switch to other

Methods: computational details of the perceptual component

div.head: Architecture and activation of the perceptual component
div.p: As illustrated in the main text, the perceptual component is based on a Deep Belief Network (DBN) having 3 layers . The first 'visible layer' is directly activated by the input from the visual sensor and hence is formed by 2352 'visible' units. The second layer ('first hidden layer') is formed by 150 'hidden' units. The third inner layer ('second hidden layer') is formed by 12 hidden units chunked in 3 groups (categories) each encompassing 4 units (attributes). The first and second layer form a first Restricted Boltzmann Machines (RBM); the second and third layer form a second RBM stacked on the first one. different actions after a correct response.

div.head: Healthy model
div.p: Extreme Perseverative model Distracted model Irrational model The DM, characterised by a high variability of decisions (high τ ), shows a lower CC than the HM (0.7 ± 0.9 vs. 5.9 ± 0.4, p < 0.001) and an error profile symmetrical with respect to the EPM. In particular, compared to the HM, it has a higher number of TE (44.3 ± 5.2 vs. 23.4 ± 5.5, p < .001), caused by 62% of NPE (27.6 ± 4.4 vs. 11.0 ± 4.2, p < .001) and 38% of PE (16.7 ± 3.7 vs. 12.4 ± 3.8, p < .001). The DM also has a higher number of FMS errors (2.9 ± 1.4 vs. 1.4 ± 1.3, p < 0.001). Despite the DM has a higher value of PE with respect to the healthy model (16.7 ± 3.7 vs. 12.4 ± 3.8, p < .001) the model is not affected by a perseverative tendency, as indicated by a higher percentage of NPE with respect to PE (62% vs 38%). This result is caused by the fact that the classic version of the WCST used here has a distortion for which a random choice of the behavioural rule (colour, form, or size) has a probability of 0.33 of resulting in a PE, so a distracted behaviour might appear as perseverative.

The IM, characterised by a high level of working-memory forgetting (high φ), has a slightly lower CC compared to the healthy model (5.6 ± 0.8 vs. 5.9 ± 0.4, p < .05) and the lowest value of TE with respect to the other altered models. In particular, it has a higher number of TE compared to the HM (29.7 ± 9.0 vs. 23.4 ± 5.5, p < .001), caused by a 52% of NPE (15.4 ± 5.7 vs. 11.0 ± 4.2, p < .001) and a 48% of PE (14.4 ± 4.5 vs. 12.4 ± 3.8, p < .05). The IM does not have a statistically different FMS value compared to the HM (1.1 ± 1.1 vs. 1.4 ± 1.3, p > .05). The fundamental deficit of this model is hence marked by a high percent of NPE with respect to PE caused by a malfunctioning of the reasoning by exclusion process. In particular, the model is not able to perform a correct reasoning because in each turn it tends to forget the previously performed actions. The increased PE can be related to the previously described distortion of the WCST for which an error caused by an erratic behaviour is scored as a perseverative error (PE).
